reviewText: I had seen this 1956 version, with Edmond O'Brien, years ago and had searched unsuccessfully for years to find a copy.  This dark, prophetic vision of the future is as chilling as the 1984 vesion with John Hurt and Richard Burton.  Although not as technically sophisticated as the newer version, it's stark use of light and shadow  contrasts paint the bleak life described by Orwell.  A "must add" to any film collector's library.
summary: Looked for this Version for Years!

reviewText: Some remakes do not live up to the original, even with superior special effects.  1984 is one of them.  The original -- this one -- gives the mundane and the horror each their place.  Because that's much of what the book is about: that the horrible loss of freedom had become so mundane, nobody attempted to question it.  This is the power of propaganda, and of mind control.  Beware.  Even more so today, beware.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Edmond O'Brien is Winston Smith. Jan Sterling is Julia. This movie did a pretty good job of depicting the story. However everyone stayed fully clothed and Goldstein's name has been changed to protect the innocent. And O'Brian becomes O'Conner.In a society that has eliminated many imbalances, surplus goods, and even class struggle, there are bound to be deviates; Winston Smith is one of those.  He starts out, due to his inability to doublethink, with thoughtcrime. This is in a society that believes a thought is as real as the deed. Eventually he graduates through a series of misdemeanors to illicit sex and even plans to overthrow the very government that took him in as an orphan.If he gets caught, he will be sent to the "Ministry of Love" where they have a record of 100% cures for this sort of insanity.  They will even forgive his past indiscretions.Be sure to watch the three different movies made from this book:1984 (1954) Peter Cushing is Winston Smith1984 (1956) Edmond O'Brien is Winston SmithNineteen Eighty-Four (1984) John Hurt is Winston smith
summary: Deviates corrected for their own good

reviewText: As another reviewer here pointed out, this appears to be an inferior transfer from a VHS copy and has a visible distortion at the bottom of the screen the entire time.It's better to have this than nothing, but the image and sound is nothing like you would expect if you bought into "remastered" when making this purchase decision.Clearly, it's not.  This looks like an old VHS tape that's been sitting in storage for a long time and has tracking issues as a result along the bottom (and the image you do see without distortion is nothing to write home about).Someone's duping the buyer here.  The two stars is because it's better than nothing.
summary: Remastered?  Who Do They Think They're Kidding?

reviewText: Classic!  Orwell's book brought to the screen with the focus on the effect of totalitarianism on a brainwashed society.  As with all such societies, there is "Big Brother," the original one, at the top, an upper, ruling class, a middle, working class made up of the workers of the society, and a lower class, relegated to what most would assume are the drgs of society.  The lower class is shown to be more than that first assumption.Two middle class members fall in love and defy the mandates of Big Brother, even to the point of wanting to overthrow the upper class.It is from Orwell's "1984" that other terms entered our lexicon, newspeak, thought police, etc.I prefer this original to the remake, though I enjoy both.  Well worth the time.  Especially if you enjoy books and films deemed to be "prophetic."

reviewText: If you have not seen this original movie of '1984' you are missing a great classic.  This was such an insightful movie of its' time. After viewing this movie you will notice the video cameras at McDonald's, banks, workplaces,public transportation hubs, street corners, at traffic light locations, etc. ..... everywhere.  Big Brother!  Big Brother!  Big Brother!Purchase this and you will want everyone you know to see it!This is the original. The remake sucks!

reviewText: The original 1984 was a fine film made with traditional values for the cinema.  I have also watched and enjoyed the remake; however, I enjoyed the original much more. Even though the sets and special effects of the first production are limited by the older film technology the original is still best in my book.Most impressive for its day were the combination of sets, flats and studio paintings used to represent the huge monument-like four sided video screen on which the latest "news" was presented to crowds screaming "Long live Big Brother" while standing in the streets in awe of his image (above the larger than life words "WAR IS PEACE", "FREEDOM IS SLAVERY" and "IGNORANCE IS STRENGTH").One writer has written in to observe that "Some of this story's predictions have come true in odd ways. Big Brother's cameras track us every day, in banks and stores, along streets and highways and even from home webcams...". I agree with this statement but offer further the fact that the future work stations of the "outer party" members have also come to pass with the standard small office cubicle having full Internet access that we toil away in every day.Much of this movie offers fresh food for thought and consideration of the following story elements: a war that continues endlessly to maintain control of the population, a government that spies on its citizens, torture endorsed and practiced on enemies of the state, the rewriting of history by the ministry of truth, state control of the press as well as the mind set of many of its citizens. The film goes on to predict that this is what will happen to our children's future unless we remain vigilant and protect it.
summary: 1984 - The Original is still the best

reviewText: With no communist threat left to fight, this film of George Orwell's sizzling book may seem like yesterday's newspaper. Still, the movie is loyal to Orwell's creation and -- having been made in Great Britain in 1956 at the height of European communism -- brings a far more potent and immediate sense of fear than that tepid remake from the 1980s.This movie features a number of stars -- Edmund O'Brien as the hero Smith, Jan Sterling as his love interest, Michael Redgrave as his boss that eventually turns him in, and a young Donald Pleasance as his friend that also meets the same fate. A highly dramatic musical score from British composer Malcolm Arnold underlines the potent story.The pace of the film varies between deadly dull and extreme nervousness while the overwhelming cinematic aura is film noir. I think this may be from poor technical detailing in the 1950s as well as a poor transfer from original film to DVD.None of this diminishes the importance of this film as a point in time reference to intolerance and authoritarism in post World War II Europe. Indeed, the voiceover at the beginning and end of the film explains how our liberty is under attack and why we must be vigilent in protecting freedom.If you read Orwell's timeless book and saw the inferior remake, it's time you see this version to get a better idea of how people actually thought about this kind of terror when communism was a menace throughout the continent. With ruthless governments still in place in Iran & North Korea, the message of inhuman domination is still relevant for today's moviegoer.
summary: A timepiece with relevance in today's Iran and North Korea

reviewText: Even while you sleep Big Brother is Watching you.  This is the 1984 movie from 1956, starring Edmond O'Brien, Michael Redgrave, and Jan Sterling.  Also you may notice David Kossoff and Donald Pleasence.  The movie follows the book very well, making a few interesting choices in the sets and props.  For example, most of the telescreens look less like television screens and more like blinking eyeballs.  Also, the scene in the mess hall when Winston and Julia are planning to meet, the food is delivered by machinery and the tables are designed to hold the tray - they are worthless for any other use.While the outside areas, and private apartments, look dirty and worn, the government offices look clean and modern.  In the 1984 movie made in 1984, everything was worn, everyplace was dirty.  There was grime in every crack, every corner.  Not so in this version - the government is clean, effective, shiny.  The people are dirty, passive, worn.91 minutes, in Black & White, a must for any fan of George Orwell.  Interesting to compare to the other visions of 1984.  I would, therefore, also suggest1984which was made in 1984 andNineteen Eighty Fourwhich was made by for BBC television.

reviewText: OK, I will admit, I am biased as I have seen and loved the John Hurt version from the 80's.  But I wanted to try something different and juxtapose the 2 cinematic versions in my mind because I am nerd in that aspect.Boy, was I ever disappointed.I did not care for the dry, slow moving pacing of the "action" and drama.  I found my self disengaged.  Although I enjoyed the hokey set pieces and fairly close adaptation of the storyline, I was not into the execution of it all. And it's not that I dislike B&W; cinema.  I just found this one...boring.AS for the quality of this product, I was unnerved to no end.  As stated in previous reviews, the sound quality is beyond poor.  There is an incessant hiss that dulls the audio and made the dialogue at times inaudible. As for the picture quality, it is fuzzy and has a distortion at the bottom of the screen that indicates this was transferred from a VHS copy.  Annoying and distracting.  I thought I could get past it, but I couldnt, especially when this version is being touted as "remastered".Avoid unless you are serious about this movie.

reviewText: Although the rating and review are primarily for this product and not the content of the film, I will say that this is an enjoyable translation to film of a novel that had wide spread popularity among my generation back in the 1950's. I can't compare it to other versions, but I do appreciate that it is reflective of the view of future technologies held during that era in which the book was conceived.As for the transfer, it's generally acceptable. The image is somewhat soft (the larger the screen, the more obvious the fuzziness) and, throughout the film, there appears to be video static lines at the very bottom of the frame (something you'd expect to see when watching a VHS tape that is slightly mis-tracking). Therefore, since this title probably has fallen into the Public Domain, I am assuming that this quite likely has been transferred from video tape. Had this been in color, I'm sure the copy would have looked even worse.The DVD-R is divided into chapters, however there is no scene selection option (in fact, there is no menu at all). Although originally released by Columbia Pictures, the beginning and end of the film identify it as a Screen Gems release (the television distribution subsidiary of Columbia Pictures). There is nothing on the packaging to indicate the origin of this DVD-R. In any event, I'm confident that this is NOT one of the burn-on-demand, studio produced DVD-Rs that are available elsewhere on Amazon.One other point, The cover art (same as displayed on Amazon) indicates the inclusion of an "Old-Time Radio Show," but it does not appear to have made it to the disc; it only contains the video for the movie. BTW, in real life, the cover art looks like a mediocre-quality photo-copy.In summary, since this title is not readily available, if you really want to watch it, you might consider this worth the price. However, if I had it to do over, for the extra few bucks I would have gotten the dual version (1954/1956) DVD (even though the quality is reportedly no better).

reviewText: This film version of Nineteen Eighty-Four was a very good interpitation for its age, but it does not compare to the later version which was filmed in 1984.  If you have read the book it would be good if you watched this version, then watched the newer version.  It has its good points and in some ways the black & white filming adds to the bleak world of Oceania.  The relationship between Winston Smith, Julia and O'Brien is differently and more fully explored in this version than the recent one, but the entire film has a different accent.  Perhaps I should explain this in Newspeak; this film is plusgood, but the newer version is doubleplusgood.  Pity they forgot that Big Brother is supposed to resemble Joseph Stalin, but don't worry; he's watching you.

reviewerName: R. E. Van Keuren "Bob Van Keuren"
reviewText: George Orwell's 1984 is a special kind of classic, a vision of a regime in which things are absolutely as bad as they can get. There have been two different, and very valuable, principal film versions. This one is black and white, which seems quite appropriate to the subject matter. It was done years before the actual year 1984, and I saw it when I was about ten years old and it made a powerful impression on me. The other was made in that very year, in London. They should both be seen and valued and discussed. I think they should someday be as a single set.
summary: This is the 1956 Version that was Unavailable for So Long

reviewText: This film, in my opinion, is far superior to the remake with Richard Burton.  This film, considering that it was made in the mid 50's was considered a breakthrough.  The telescreen was actually, a Zenith 30 inch prototype tv tube, under testing that was loaned to the studio in England.  The screen was enchanced (made bigger) and edited into the film using at that time, state of the art equipment.  Excellent musical score, acting was superb.  I highly recommend the purchase of this DVD.

reviewText: This 1956 vision starts with scenes from the recurring nightmare of its time: nuclear war. Oceania and the rest were built on the glowing rubble of that war.Michael Anderson directed this very compelling version of Winston Smith, the Everyman in that world. It's a world where people searched daily, in their own homes - display of pockets and briefcase content in front of the flickering but unblinking monitor lenses. His work is in rewriting history, to make sure everything turned out the way Big Brother says that it did, and rewriting again tomorrow to conform to the new past.This movie form of Orwell's book does take some liberties with the story, but none that matter. Winston and his lover are captured. Their thoughtcrime is too serious for matters like trial, and the sentence is immediate. They don't deserve execution in that world, instead they are crushed into Big Brother's mold and converted. This is not a movie with a happy ending. At the time it was written, though, it was a very believable ending.Some of this story's predictions have some true, in odd ways. Big Brother's cameras track us every day, in banks and stores, along streets and highways, and even from home webcams. Oddly, the futuristic dome-towers of Orwell's Ministry buildings in London also came true in the Swiss Re building, the "gherkin.".In other ways, though, the 1950s sensibilities of the movie look stale to a modern audience. A newer version of the movie emphasized the grit and damage of a bombed-out world, impoverished by the costs of its weapons, but this was a relatively clean kind of place. The newer production also suggested the physical decay caused by imprisonment under Big Brother, but this Winston came out looking reasonably well-fed and dapper. The 1956 Winston was a crushed man, too, but our eyes have changed since this movie was made.Still, it's a classic rendering of a classic cautionary story. It's a strong portrayal of a dystopia that could still happen, even though calendar year 1984 has come and gone. And, like Orwell's original, it ends on a note in which hope is not just gone, but forgotten.//wiredweird
